description.narrative: The Pan-American Development Foundation (PADF/FUPAD) i Colombia har ansökt om finansiering från Sida om 4 800 000 SEK för perioden 2017–2020. Insatsen övergripande mål är att stödja offentlig antikorruptionspolitik, medborgerlig delaktighet och ansvarsutkrävande för att förbättra offentlig förvaltning, samhällsservice och transparens. Insatsen har tre specifika mål: 1) Främja medborgarnas deltagande genom att stärka människors kunskap och förmåga att bekämpa korruption. 2) Stärka offentliga institutioner så att de införlivar förfaranden som främjar administrativ effektivitet, bästa praxis och transparens, och 3) Främja förtroendeskapande och transparanta processer genom att underlätta dialogen mellan medborgare och offentligt anställda.

The Pan-American Development Foundation (PADF/FUPAD) in Colombia has applied to Sida for funding of 4 800 000 SEK during the period 2017-2020. The overall objective of the intervention is to promote anti-corruption policies, citizen participation and accountability to improve public management, service delivery and transparency. The intervention has three specific objectives: 1. Promoting citizen participation by strengthening people’s knowledge and capabilities to fight against corruption; 2. Strengthening public institutions to incorporate procedures that promote administrative efficiency, best practices and transparency; and 3. Fostering trust-building and transparency processes, by facilitating dialogue between citizens and public servants.

description.narrative: The Anti-corruption Fund supported four projects throughout its operation, three of which were implemented through contracts/subgrants with Transparencia por Colombia (TpC), the national chapter of Transparency International, and one with the national media company Proyectos Semana S.A. The Fund established three strategic intervention areas: 1. Promoting dialogue and dissemination processes; 2. Institutional strengthening; 3. Building trust between citizens and public officials to foster accountability. Three of the supported projects were in line with each of these areas, while the fourth project integrated them through a more comprehensive strategy. In the first intervention area, to promote dialogue and dissemination processes to fight corruption, the Fund supported the regional seminar “Corruption in Colombia: The worst form of violence”, organized by Proyectos Semana S.A. in Tumaco, Nariño, in 2017. This municipality has been deeply affected by the armed conflict and suffers from a historic absence of State institutions and services. 88 people participated in the seminar, including representatives of public institutions, the private sector, civil society organizations and universities. A communication campaign was developed in parallel to the event through social networks and traditional media at the national and local levels, which raised awareness on corruption as a form of violence and an obstacle for peacebuilding. The second intervention area intended to promote institutional strengthening to adopt anticorruption practices, through an agreement with TpC aimed at designing a methodology for calculating the social damage derived from corruption cases and incorporate this estimation into judicial processes and administrative reparations. As a result, TpC developed a practical instrument to measure the social damage of corruption crimes in consultation with judicial authorities and independent control institutions. The Ministry of Justice was actively involved in the implementation of this project and was the main recipient of the tools developed to estimate the social damage of corruption. Although the methodology has not yet been adopted formally, the contribution’s evaluation found that it was used as an input for an anticorruption bill proposal and serves as a reference for judicial authorities. The third intervention area aimed at building trust between citizens and public officials to promote transparency and accountability at the local level. For this, the Fund supported the project “Civic mobilization for anticorruption in Cali, Cartagena and Pereira” implemented by Transparencia por Colombia. Results of this intervention include the strengthening of TpC’s Center for Anticorruption Legal Assistance (ALAC by its Spanish acronym) by disseminating information on its work, conducting workshops in four and providing legal support in five new corruption complaints. Furthermore, through the methodology “Corruptour” and communication strategies, citizens were informed on the impact of corruption on collective wellbeing, as well as on mechanisms to denounce corruption and promote electoral transparency. A dissemination event on how to fight corruption was also conducted with entrepreneurs and private sector representatives. Also, this initiative produced a document with recommendations on how to improve electoral transparency to prevent corruption in Colombia. The last project “Protect peacebuilding in sectors and regions with high corruption risks” was also implemented by TpC but incorporated a more comprehensive approach through cross-cutting strategies, a longer activity period and increased funding. This intervention was designed based on learned lessons from previous projects and managed to exceed initial expectations and planned results, which is particularly impressive considering it was mostly implemented under exceptional conditions derived from the Covid-19 emergency. Its main objective was to This initiative provided anticorruption training and practical tools to denounce corruption to 76 civic leaders representing 40 civil society organizations from two of the most conflict-affected territories (Cauca and Caquetá). It is noteworthy that 58% of participants in the trainings were women and the project had a significant participation of LGBTI, indigenous and afrocolombian people, as well as rural dwellers. The project also produced three citizen oversight reports on the implementation of the Peace Agreement between the Government of Colombia and FARC-EP, one at the national level and two in each of the prioritized regions. These reports resulted in the identification of 18 corruption risk factors and the design of a risk mitigation plan and public management guidelines that were presented to the public and authorities. Also, the project managed to advocate from increased protection of corruption whistleblowers, provide legal assistance in three cases of citizens’ complaints of corruption and disseminate information on how to denounce corruption. The implementation of several digital strategies for anticorruption training, advocacy and information were developed due to lockdowns derived from the Covid-19 pandemic. These digital tools allowed to reach a higher number of participants, strengthen connectivity skills for civic leaders and reach broader audiences in public events than initially planned, configuring unintended results for this project.
